facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 398 of 1956 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 398 of 1956. Appeal from the judgment and order dated March

facts.text: Appeal against Bombay High Court judgment dated March 19, 1956 in Appeal No. 45 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated March 19, 1956, of the Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 45 of 1955,

facts.text: Arising from Bombay High Court judgment dated March 23, 1956 in Suit No. 468 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and order dated March 23, 1956, of the said High Court in its Ordinary Original Civil. Jurisdiction in Suit No. 468 of 1951.

facts.text: Suit No. 468 of 1951 instituted by appellants (original plaintiffs) to recover Rs. 1,80,099-8-0 from respondents (original defendants).

anchor.surface_text: Suit No. 468 of 1951 instituted by the appellants  Original Plaintiffs  to recover from the respon- dents  Original Defendants  a sum of Rs. 1,80,099-8-0 with interest and companymts.

facts.text: First appellant has been member of East India Cotton Association Ltd. since 1932 as sole proprietor of Messrs. Narrondass Manordass (member firm).

anchor.surface_text: Since the year 1932 the first appellant has been a member of the East India Cotton Association Ltd.,  hereinafter referred to as the Association   as the sole proprietor of the firm of Messrs. Narrondass Manordass

facts.text: First appellant along with other partners carried on business as Cotton Merchants and Commission Agents in name Messrs. Narrondass Manordass (partnership firm).

anchor.surface_text: There in after referred to as the member firm . The first appellant along with other partners carried on business in partnership in Bombay inter alia as Cotton Merchants and Commission Agents in the name and style of Messrs. Narrondass Manordass,

facts.text: Respondents are a partnership firm and member of the Association.

anchor.surface_text: the 2nd appellant  hereinafter referred to as the partnership firm  . The respondents are a partnership firm and also a member of the Association.

facts.text: Between September 23, 1947, and December 10, 1947, member firm sold 2,300 bales of Broach Vijay Fine 3/4 Navsari and/or Bardoli 7/8 Cotton to respondents for March-April 1948 delivery.

anchor.surface_text: Between September 23, 1947, and December 10, 1947, the member firm sold to the respondents 2,300 bales of Broach Vijay Fine 3/4 Navsari and or Bardoli 7/8 Cotton for March April 1948 Delivery.

facts.text: Out of 2,300 bales, 1,100 bales disposed of by Havalas, remaining 1,200 bales had cross-contracts, resulting in 700 bales outstanding.

anchor.surface_text: Out of these 2,300 bales, 1,100 bales were disposed of by means of Havalas and in respect of the remaining 1,200 bales, there were cross- compantracts.

facts.text: Member firm failed to deliver 700 bales to respondents.

anchor.surface_text: In the result when the time for Delivery arrived, sales in respect of 700 bales remained outstanding and the member firm was liable to give delivery of 700 bales to the respondents.

facts.text: Respondents invoiced back 700 bales to member firm on May 3, 1948, resulting in Rs. 1,07,530-8-0 due, total Rs. 1,79,749-8-0 for all transactions.

anchor.surface_text: As however, the member firm failed to give delivery of the said 700 bales to the respondents, under the relevant by-laws of the Association, the respondents Invoiced Back these 700 bales to the member firm on May 3, 1948,

facts.text: Respondents sent eight separate Debit Notes and consolidated debit note for Rs. 1,79,749-8-0.

anchor.surface_text: and as a result of this Invoicing Back a sum of Rs. 1,07,530-8-0 became due and payable by the member firm to the respondents and with regard to the transactions of all the 2,300 bales

facts.text: Contract notes signed by Ramanlal Nagindas, salesman in Ready Cotton Department of partnership firm.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the compantract numberees in respect of these transactions had been signed by one Ramanlal Nagindas who had been employed as a salesman in the Ready Cotton Department of the partnership firm.

facts.text: Appellants contended Ramanlal Nagindas had no authority to enter transactions or sign contract notes, and contracts not in accordance with by-laws.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants compannted that the said Ramanlal Nagindas had numberauthority to enter into the said transactions or to sign compantract numberees in respect thereof on behalf of the appellants

facts.text: Partnership firm paid Rs. 1,79,748-8-0 to respondents on May 7, 1948, without prejudice.

anchor.surface_text: The partnership firm, however, as the beneficiary under the said compantracts decided to pay the amounts claimed by the respon- dents without prejudice to the rights and companntions of both the parties.

facts.text: Further Rs. 350 penalty paid by partnership firm on June 6, 1948, without prejudice.

anchor.surface_text: A further sum of Rs. 350 being the amount of penalty for the alleged failure to tender the aforesaid 700 bales of the said compantracts of Broach Vijay March April 1948 Delivery, was also paid

facts.text: Ramanlal Nagindas entered similar transactions with other merchants; petitions A/51, A/52, A/55, A/56 of 1949 filed under s.33 Arbitration Act.

anchor.surface_text: The said Ramanlal Nagindas had entered into similar transactions with several other merchants and some of them claimed arbitration under by-law 38-A of the Association. Petitions were thereupon filed

facts.text: Mr. Justice Shah held contracts void on August 20, 1950 in those petitions.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Justice Shah delivered judgment in the said petitions on August 20, 1950, holding inter alia that the said compantracts were void as being number in accordance with the by- laws of the Association

facts.text: Petitions under Art. 226 Constitution for special leave dismissed by Supreme Court on April 6, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents to the petitions thereupon filed petitions under Art. 136 of the Constitution for special leave to appeal to this Court against the said judgment of Mr. Justice Shah.

facts.text: Appellants demanded return of Rs. 1,80,099-8-0 by letter dated May 2, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants thereafter by their attorneys letter dated May 2, 1951, called upon the respondents to return the said sum of I-Is. 1,80,099-8-0

facts.text: Suit filed on May 7, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents failed and neglected to pay to the appellants the said sum or any part thereof with the result that on May 7, 1951, the appellants filed the suit

facts.text: Appellants averred contracts void under Bombay Cotton Contracts Act, 1932 for omitting difference vs settlement rate (bylaws 139,141) and measurement (bylaw 80).

anchor.surface_text: In the plaint as filed the appellants averred that the said compantracts were void under the Bombay Cotton Contracts Act, 1932, as being number in accordance with the by-laws of the Association inter alia in the following respects

facts.text: Respondents contended no by-law required stating difference above/below settlement rate; provisions obsolete as no hedge contracts for settlements; by-law 101 suspended since Nov 30, 1942.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents in their written statement compannted that there was numberby-law which required any person to agree upon any difference above or below the settlement rate of hedge compantracts

facts.text: Trial Judge (single Judge) held contracts void due to omission of difference term, no implied agreement, dismissed suit.

anchor.surface_text: The learned trial Judge followed the judgment of Mr. Justice Shah and held that the omission of the clause regarding measurement in the compantract numberees did number alter the character

facts.text: Appellate High Court confirmed dismissal on different grounds: measurement omission immaterial, no obligation for difference term, but implied agreement exists; contracts valid.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants preferred ail, appeal against this decision and the appellate Court dismissed the appeal and confirmed the decree passed by the learned trial Judge, though on different grounds.

facts.text: Board suspended operation of by-law 101 on November 30, 1942.

anchor.surface_text: The Board of Directors issued a numberice on November 30, 1942, suspending the operation of bylaw 101 as regards the measurement until further numberice.

facts.text: Supreme Court held contracts in accordance with by-laws, not void; appellants not entitled to recover.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of the opinion that the omission to fill in those blanks in the compantract numberees did number spell any departure from an essential or a characteristic part

facts.text: Delivery contracts not put through periodical settlements in practice.

anchor.surface_text: The effect of this procedure being adopted in the Association was tacitly to suspend the operation of these by-laws as to periodical settlements in respect of delivery compantracts

issues.text: whether the contracts between the parties were not in accordance with the by-laws of the Association and therefore void

anchor.surface_text: The only question for our determination in this appeal is whether the contracts between the parties were not in accordance with the by-laws of the Association and therefore void.

issues.text: whether omission to state the difference of Rs above or below the settlement rate of hedge contracts for the purpose of periodical settlements as required by by-laws 139 and 141 renders the contracts void

anchor.surface_text: In the plaint as filed the appellants averred that the said contracts were void under the Bombay Cotton Contracts Act, 1932, as being not in accordance with the by-laws of the Association inter alia in the following respects 1 The contract notes produced by the respondents omitted to state the difference of Rs above or below the settlement rate of hedge contracts for the purpose of periodical settlements as required by by-laws 139 and 141

issues.text: whether no provision with regard to the measurement of bales as required by the official form for delivery contracts prescribed in by-law 80 renders the contracts void

anchor.surface_text: and 2 no provision was made in any of the aforesaid contract notes with regard to the measurement of bales as required by the official form for delivery contracts prescribed in bylaw 80. The respondents in their written statement contended that there was no by-law which required any person to agree upon any difference above or below the settlement rate of hedge contracts

issues.text: whether the parties were bound to enter into any such agreement [on difference above or below the settlement rate] at the time they entered into the contracts

anchor.surface_text: The question arises as to whether the parties were bound to enter into any such agreement at the time they entered into the contracts. It was contended on behalf of the appellants that such an agreement was necessary because it would otherwise involve the parties into payment of large sums of money on the settlement day next after the day of the contract.

issues.text: whether there was an implied agreement between the parties that in the event of the appellants establishing that they were not bound to pay the said sums to the respondents and that the respondents were not entitled to the payment thereof the respondents would repay or return the same to the appellants

anchor.surface_text: After the suit reached hearing the appellants amended the plaint by averring that by reason of the said payments having been made by them and accepted by the respondents without prejudice to the rights and contentions of both the parties there was an implied agreement between them that in the event of the appellants establishing that they were not bound to pay the said sums to the respondents and that the respondents were not entitled to the payment thereof the respondents would repay or return the same to the appellants.

holdings.text: The omission to mention the measurements in the contract notes did not render the contracts not in accordance with the by-laws.

anchor.surface_text: The Board of Directors issued a notice on November 30, 1942, suspending the operation of bylaw 101 as regards the measurement until further notice. The position as it obtained at the time when the suit contracts were entered into was that by-law 101 as regards measurement had been suspended and there was no necessity so far as the by-laws went to make any mention in the contracts in regard to the same.

holdings.reasoning_summary: By-law 101 suspended since 1942; no operational by-law requiring measurement term; substantial compliance with form sufficient; no departure from characteristic part or change in legal effect.

holdings.text: The omission to fill in those blanks in the contract notes [regarding difference above/below settlement rate] did not spell any departure from an essential or a characteristic part of the contract form nor was the legal effect of the contracts in any manner changed thereby rendering the contracts void within the meaning of s. 8 of the Bombay Cotton Contracts Act, 1932.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of the opinion that the omission to fill in those blanks in the contract notes did not spell any departure from an essential or a characteristic part of the contract form nor was the legal effect of the contracts in any manner changed thereby rendering the contracts void within the meaning of s. 8 of the Bombay Cotton Contracts Act, 1932.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No obligation to agree on difference (unfilled implies nil per by-law 141); parties not bound to fill if no agreement; substantial compliance per precedent; term obsolete as delivery contracts not subject to periodical settlements in practice.

holdings.text: Both these grounds of attack against the validity of the contracts in question therefore fail and we are of the opinion that the contracts entered into between the appellants and the respondents were not void as alleged.

anchor.surface_text: Both these grounds of attack against the validity of the contracts in question therefore fail and we are of the opinion that the contracts entered into between the appellants and the respondents were not void as alleged. The appellants were therefore not entitled to recover from the respondents the said sum of Rs. 1,80,099-8-0 or any part thereof as alleged or at all

holdings.reasoning_summary: Omissions in form do not constitute departure from essential/characteristic parts due to suspension/obsolescence; substantial compliance suffices per Radhakisson; applies s.8 Bombay Cotton Contracts Act.

holdings.text: The appellants were therefore not entitled to recover from the respondents the said sum of Rs. 1,80,099-8-0 or any part thereof as alleged or at all and ... the appellate Court was right in rejecting the appellants claim.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants were therefore not entitled to recover from the respondents the said sum of Rs. 1,80,099-8-0 or any part thereof as alleged or at all and we are of the opinion that the appellate Court was right in rejecting the appellants claim.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contracts valid, so no basis for recovery of payments made thereunder.

holdings.text: delivery contracts were not put through any periodical settlements and at all material times the operation of this term in the official contract form had become obsolete ... tacitly to suspend the operation of these by-laws as to periodical settlements in respect of delivery contracts.

anchor.surface_text: The effect of this procedure being adopted in the Association was tacitly to suspend the operation of these by-laws as to periodical settlements in respect of delivery contracts and it would be superfluous, nay absurd, on the part of the business people entering into contracts subject to the by-laws of the Association to incorporate in the contract form provisions which had become obsolete.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Trade practice of not settling delivery contracts periodically renders by-laws 139/141 inoperative tacitly; no need to comply with obsolete form terms.

holdings.text: if the parties to the contracts intended not to comply with the requirements of by-laws 139 and 141 that would by itself vitiate the contracts ... [but] we do not feel called upon to consider the same in view of the fact that that was not the ground on which the validity of the suit contract was challenged in the plaint.

anchor.surface_text: It was, however, urged on behalf of the appellants that if the parties to the contracts intended not to comply with the requirements of by-laws 139 and 141 that would by itself vitiate the contracts because in that event the contracts would certainly be not in accordance with the by-laws of the Association. ... There is considerable force in this argument but we do not feel called upon to consider the same

holdings.reasoning_summary: Argument has force but not decided as not pleaded; obiter acknowledgment.

anchor.surface_text: Radhakisson Gopikisson v. Balmukund Ramchandra  1 . Their Lordships of the Privy Council there held that the form prescribed was number a stereotyped one and that literal companypliance with it was number essential. The only thing required was that the companytract numberes must companytain all the terms and companyditions set out in the form in order to companyply with it.

precedents.cited_proposition: The expression 'not in accordance with' requires substantial compliance with the prescribed form, not literal compliance; contracts are saved from voidness if they contain all essential terms and conditions.
precedents.cited_holding: the form prescribed was number a stereotyped one and that literal companypliance with it was number essential. The only thing required was that the companytract numberes must companytain all the terms and companyditions set out in the form in order to companyply with it... substantial companypliance with the form would be enough

anchor.surface_text: Burchell v. Thompson  1 , Ex-parte Stanford, In re Barber  2 , Thomas v. Kelly  3  and Parsons v. Brand Cols v. Dickson  4 . The principle emerging from these decisions was enunciated to be that if the document executed by and between the parties departed from a characteristic part of the form prescribed or made a difference in the legal effect of the instrument, it would number be in accordance with the form and would therefore be void.

precedents.cited_proposition: If a document departs from a characteristic part of the prescribed form or alters the legal effect of the instrument, it is not in accordance with the form and is void.

anchor.surface_text: Ex-parte Stanford, In re Barber  2 , Thomas v. Kelly  3  and Parsons v. Brand Cols v. Dickson  4 . The principle emerging from these decisions was enunciated to be that if the document executed by and between the parties departed from a characteristic part of the form prescribed or made a difference in the legal effect of the instrument, it would number be in accordance with the form and would therefore be void. It would all depend upon the materiality of the -particular term which is incorporated in the form.

precedents.cited_proposition: If a document departs from a characteristic part of the prescribed form or alters the legal effect of the instrument, it is not in accordance with the form and is void.

anchor.surface_text: Thomas v. Kelly  3  and Parsons v. Brand Cols v. Dickson  4 . The principle emerging from these decisions was enunciated to be that if the document executed by and between the parties departed from a characteristic part of the form prescribed or made a difference in the legal effect of the instrument, it would number be in accordance with the form and would therefore be void. It would all depend upon the materiality of the particular term which is incorporated in the form.

precedents.cited_proposition: If a document departs from a characteristic part of the prescribed form or alters the legal effect of the instrument, it is not in accordance with the form and is void.

precedents.citation: Parsons v. Brand Cols v. Dickson  4

anchor.surface_text: Parsons v. Brand Cols v. Dickson  4 . The principle emerging from these decisions was enunciated to be that if the document executed by and between the parties departed from a characteristic part of the form prescribed or made a difference in the legal effect of the instrument, it would number be in accordance with the form and would therefore be void. It would all depend upon the materiality of the -particular term which is incorporated in the form. If the number-compliance with the requirements of the form were such as to make the document something else by reason of a characteristic part of the form number being followed or the document would lose some legal effect which it would have had if the proper words had been inserted therein, it cannot be said that there is sub- stantial companypliance with the statutory form.

precedents.case_name: Parsons v. Brand Cols v. Dickson
precedents.cited_proposition: If a document departs from a characteristic part of the prescribed form or alters the legal effect of the instrument, it is not in accordance with the form and is void.

anchor.surface_text: Both these grounds of attack against the validity of the contracts in question therefore fail and we are of the opinion that the contracts entered into between the appellants and the respondents were not void as alleged. The appellants were therefore not entitled to recover from the respondents the said sum of Rs. 1,80,099-8-0 or any part thereof as alleged or at all and we are of the opinion that the appellate Court was right in rejecting the appellants claim.

anchor.surface_text: The Board of Directors issued a notice on November 30, 1942, suspending the operation of bylaw 101 as regards the measurement until further notice. The position as it obtained at the time when the suit contracts were entered into was that by-law 101 as regards measurement had been suspended and there was no necessity so far as the by-laws went to make any mention in the contracts in regard to the same.

Both these grounds of attack against the validity of the contracts in question therefore fail and we are of the opinion that the contracts entered into between the appellants and the respondents were not void as alleged. The appellants were therefore not entitled to recover from the respondents the said sum of Rs. 1,80,099-8-0 or any part thereof as alleged or at all and we are of the opinion that the appellate Court was right in rejecting the appellants claim.

anchor.surface_text: The effect of this procedure being adopted in the Association was tacitly to suspend the operation of these by-laws as to periodical settlements in respect of delivery contracts and it would be superfluous, nay absurd, on the part of the business people entering into contracts subject to the by-laws of the Association to incorporate in the contract form provisions which had become obsolete.

Both these grounds of attack against the validity of the contracts in question therefore fail and we are of the opinion that the contracts entered into between the appellants and the respondents were not void as alleged. The appellants were therefore not entitled to recover from the respondents the said sum of Rs. 1,80,099-8-0 or any part thereof as alleged or at all and we are of the opinion that the appellate Court was right in rejecting the appellants claim.
